did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Primary and secondary source genealogical materials related to Guilford families, including tax lists, merchant ledgers, published genealogies, and files of information compiled by museum staff.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Henry Whitfield State Museum.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], , [Box no]., Henry Whitfield State Museum

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The Henry Whitfield State Museum, established by the State of Connecticut in 1899, explores four centuries of Connecticut history through the evolution of the 1639 Whitfield House. Thirty-two years after the founding of Jamestown and nineteen years after the Pilgrims landed at Plymouth, a group of English Puritans journeyed across the Atlantic Ocean to establish a community in the New World free from religious persecution. They were led by their minister, Reverend Henry Whitfield. The Whitfield family home also served as a fort for the community. Its massive stone walls and chimneys, steeply-pitched roof, and casement windows reflect the style of post-medieval domestic architecture found in England - rare in 17th-century America and unique today. Through the years, the "Old Stone House" has undergone many changes and many families have called it home. Restored by noted architects Norman Isham and J. Frederick Kelly in the early 1900s, the house is an important example of Colonial Revival restoration work. Based on these restorations, the Whitfield House was designated a National Historic Landmark. The museum and library collections number over 10,000 items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Primary and secondary source genealogical materials related to Guilford families.
Tax lists - Guilford (1794, 1798, 1816, 1818, 1823, 1827), North Guilford (1754-1755, 1799, 1807, c. 1808), East Guilford/Madison (1797-1798), and North Bristol/North Madison (1798)
Guilford town records including meeting minutes and committee reports (broken records c. 1740-1819)
The Bill of Mortality (listing of deaths in Guilford, 1746-1840)
Other miscellaneous material, including documents, property deeds, organizations' records, letters, etc.
Files of information compiled by museum staff (2 file drawers)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In general, the materials are stored by format and size and arranged by subject. For instance, all of the tax lists are in archival boxes and arranged by date while the published genealogies are on shelves and arranged alphabetically by family name.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.subject: Genealogy
Taxation--Lists
